entries.meaning: A general confusion or muddle, especially of a large number of items.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:hodgepodge

verbs.description: welter (third-person singular simple present welters, present participle weltering, simple past and past participle weltered)

examples: And behind, the tempest fleet
Hurries on with lightning feet,
Riving sail, and cord, and plank,
Till the ship has almost drank
Death from the oâ€™er-brimming deep;
And sinks down, down, like that sleep
When the dreamer seems to be
Weltering through eternity;
When we welter in pleasures and idleness, then we eat and drink with drunkards.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of waves, billows) To rise and fall, to tumble over, to roll.
examples: Such Musick (as â€™tis said)
Before was never made,
But when of old the sons of morning sung,
While the Creator Great
His constellations set,
And the well-ballancâ€™t world on hinges hung,
And cast the dark foundations deep,
And bid the weltring waves their oozy channel keep.
a welter race

verbs.description: welter (third-person singular simple present welters, present participle weltering, simple past and past participle weltered)

examples: But look now into the weltered hearts and blighted memories of those whom we have gathered from out of the thousands of the lost and wretched.
